entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, slang) The act of bludging.

examples: ‘Seriously, you′ve got sheep at school?’ I said.
‘Yeah, heaps of kids here do Ag. Reckon it′s a big bludge, like drama.’

verbs.description: bludge (third-person singular simple present bludges, present participle bludging, simple past and past participle bludged)

entries.meaning: (Australia, obsolete, slang) To live off the earnings of a prostitute.
(Australia, New Zealand, slang) To not earn one's keep, to live off someone else or off welfare when one could be working.
(Australia, New Zealand, slang) To avoid one's responsibilities; to leave it to others to perform duties that one is expected to perform.
examples: One of the mess orderlies had consistently bludged on the rest of us all day.

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, slang) To do nothing, to be idle, especially when there is work to be done.
examples: Now, you get back out there and you bludge! I don't want to see anyone working, OK? I don't want to see any pick-axes, any hammers, or nothing.

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, slang) To take some benefit and give nothing in return.
examples: Can I bludge a cigarette off you?
